metadata.case_name: State of Bihar & Ors. v. Bhabapritananda Ojha

facts.text: The Baidyanath temple is situate in the town of Deoghar within the limits of Santal Parganas in the State of Bihar. History goes back to remote antiquity per Hindu tradition in Siva Purana and Padma Purana, and Santal tradition.
Temple shelters lingam dedicated to Mahadeva in stone-paved quadrangular courtyard containing eleven other smaller temples. Pilgrims make offerings of flowers, money, valuables, rent-free land.
High priest (Sardar Panda) paid fixed rent to Rajas of Birbhum during Muhammadan regime. About 300 families of pandas (Maithil Brahmins) attached to temple.
In 1787, British Government organized establishment of priests, collectors, watchmen at Government expense, but revenue fell off due to chief priest's emissaries.

In 1791, Government relinquished claim to offerings, entrusted management to head priest Ram Dutt (ancestor of respondent) on agreement to keep temples in repair and perform ceremonies. Income estimated at Rs. 2,000 then Rs. 25,000.

Mismanagement complaints: temple/ghats out of repair, alienation of villages. On death of high priest in 1820, dispute between uncle and nephew; Nityanand appointed then removed for malversation, Sarbanand appointed 1823.
In 1835, Government declined interference, parties to resort to courts. Sarbanand died 1837, succeeded by son Iswaranund Ojha, then grandson Sailajanund Ojha.

Suit No. 18 of 1897 under s.539 (now s.92) CPC in District Judge Burdwan. Sailajanund Ojha dismissed July 4, 1901 as unfit. Scheme framed: three persons appointed, one from descendants of Ram Dutt Jha. Umesbanund Dutt Jha elected.
Scheme confirmed by Calcutta High Court in Shailajananda Dut Jha v. Umeshanunda Dut Jha (1905) 2 C.L.J. 460.
Scheme modified 1909-1910: Calcutta HC inserted clauses reserving liberty to apply to District Court Burdwan or HC for scheme directions/modification, per Prayag Doss v. Tirumala.

Committee applied to Burdwan DJ for directions; HC directed annual budget, quarterly audit, joint control of funds, no undue interference with priest, no pecuniary interest members. Reported in Umeshananda Dutta Jha v. Sir Ravaneswar Prasad Singh (1912) 17 C.W.N. 871.
On death of Umeshanund, Bhabapritananda Ojha (grandson of Sailajanund, respondent) appointed Sardar Panda.
Bihar Hindu Religious Trusts Act, 1950 (Bihar I of 1951) assented Feb 21, 1951, force Aug 15, 1951. Established Bihar State Board of Religious Trusts.
Aug 1952, Board President under s.59 asked respondent for statement re temple properties. Respondent replied administration under Burdwan DJ/Calcutta HC scheme, Act inapplicable.
Board assessed fee Rs. 1,684-6-6 under s.70.
Respondent filed application under Art.226 Constitution in Patna HC (Misc. Judicial Case No. 181/1953): Act ultra vires or inapplicable to temple due to scheme by courts outside Bihar.
Patna HC Oct 9, 1953: construed 'religious trust' s.2(1) to exclude trusts under schemes by courts outside Bihar; quashed proceedings, prohibited further action.
Appellants obtained certificate under Art.132, appealed.
Baidyanath temple is public trust, as held in earlier litigation; properties mainly in Bihar, some in West Bengal (Burdwan, Murshidabad, Birbhum).

legal_issues.text: Whether the Bihar Hindu Religious Trusts Act, 1950 applies to Baidyanath temple administered under scheme by District Judge Burdwan and Calcutta High Court situate outside Bihar territorial limits.
Whether the Act suffers from extra-territorial operation by interfering with jurisdiction of courts outside Bihar or by applying to properties outside Bihar.
Whether doctrine of comity of jurisdictions requires cutting down scope of 'religious trust' in s.2(1) to exclude such trusts.

petitioner_arguments.text: High Court erred in relying on comity of jurisdictions to cut down Act's scope; no conflict possible as s.4(5) makes s.92 CPC inapplicable to trusts in Bihar, so no clash with courts outside Bihar.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Item 28 Concurrent List; s.4(5) Bihar Act; s.3 Bihar Act; Art.245 Constitution

petitioner_arguments.text: Act not extra-territorial: applies if trust/institution in Bihar and part property in Bihar; Bihar Legislature competent re religious endowments in State.
Act upheld against Art.14,19(1)(f),25,26,27 challenges and as not unauthorised tax in other appeals (Nos.225 etc.); not private trust; no extra-territoriality per Appeal No.230/1955.

respondent_arguments.text: Suit No.18/1897 still pending; Burdwan DJ/Calcutta HC in seizin; Act interferes with their jurisdiction, has extra-territorial operation re ss.3,4(5),28,29.
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: Art.245 Constitution; Letters Patent cl.39 Patna HC; s.29 Bihar Act

respondent_arguments.text: Scheme modifiable only by Calcutta HC; Feb 9,1917 Calcutta HC decision: applications to Burdwan DJ not Dumka DC.
Act ultra vires or inapplicable as conflicts with courts outside Bihar jurisdiction.

court_reasoning.text: Act previously upheld against fundamental rights/tax challenges (Appeals 225 etc.); not private trust (Appeal 343/1955); no extra-territoriality if trust and part property in Bihar (Appeal 230/1955).
court_reasoning.key_observation: Two conditions fulfilled: temple in Bihar, properties mainly in Bihar.

court_reasoning.text: No comity issue or international law conflict. No extra-territoriality in s.3 re outside property (per Appeal 230). s.4(5) validly removes s.92 CPC jurisdiction for Bihar trusts; no interference with outside courts as they exercised under s.92 which ends.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Bihar Legislature can amend CPC (Concurrent List item 13) for Bihar endowments; President's assent, Art.254(2).

court_reasoning.text: s.29: Board superintends committees; if Act valid, applies fully; no need to cut down scope.
court_reasoning.key_observation: No conflict if Act good; territorial nexus sufficient.

court_reasoning.text: Unnecessary to decide if Suit 18/1897 pending or Letters Patent effect; hinges on s.92 applicability.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Act binding on all courts if valid.

holdings.text: Act and provisions do not suffer from extra-territoriality; good and applies to Baidyanath temple and properties.
s.4(5) validly ends s.92 CPC jurisdiction for Bihar religious trusts; no conflict with outside courts.
No basis to cut down 'religious trust' definition per comity.

outcome.summary: Appeal allowed with costs; judgment/order of Patna High Court dated October 9, 1953 set aside; Act applies to Baidyanath temple.
outcome.relief_granted: Quashing of HC order permitting Board proceedings.

key_quotes.text: the Act is good and applies to the Baidyanath temple and the properties appertaining thereto.
